text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another kitchen conundrum for you a
thanksgiving conundrum now many
americans fry their turkeys at
thanksgiving or they smoke their turkeys
they make grilled or turkeys and they're
left with the predicament of how to make
gravy without those delicious pan
drippings well today i'm gonna show you
how you can have your fried turkey here
or your smoked turkey and your gravy too
and it's very very simple and all you
really need to do is start with a stock
so you have the neck and you have the
giblets from inside the turkey and to
start the stock we're going to add those
to a small saucepan here i have a little
bit of aromatics I like to use celery
one onion that's quartered and a bay
leaf and four cups of water you just
want to cover your ingredients here
bring this up to a boil and you're gonna
reduce it to a simmer until the liquid
has reduced to about two and a half cups
and then we'll be ready to make our
delicious gravy so our turkey stock is
slowly coming up to a boil and now for
the real trick here to get those
delicious pan drippings that you don't
have from your turkey now if your
butcher has turkey wings available or
turkey drumsticks any turkey parts and
you can purchase them get three pounds
of that if not you can always use
chicken wings and that's what I'm gonna
use here today so I have three pounds of
chicken wings and I'm gonna toss them
into a large roasting pan and season
them up with lots of salt and pepper now
make sure your oven is preheated to 425
degrees and these wings are going to
roast until they're nice dark brown in
color and the Fond or the brown bits on
the bottom of the pan are bubbling and
juicing about an hour to an hour and a
half our chicken wings are nicely
roasted you can see all of the
caramelized bits on the bottom of the
pan and that is the real flavor our
stock is nice and reduced here so I'm
just gonna strain our turkey stock and
I'm gonna remove the chicken wings from
the roasting pan I have a fat separator
year I'm just going to drain any juices
in the bottom of the pan and what's
gonna happen is the fats gonna rise to
the top and the juices are gonna sink to
the bottom which makes it easy to take
out all of that fat our roasting pan
with those wonderful bits at the bottom
right on to the heat here and I'm gonna
turn this on and we're going to deglaze
the pan to deglaze with a little bit of
stock I'm gonna add about a cup of stock
to the roasting pan the wonderful
caramelized bits are coming off of the
bottom of the roasting pan and this
needs to come up to a boil now and while
that's happening I'm going to show you
how to thicken your gravy the easiest
way I think to thicken your gravy so
take the remaining stock that you have
and 1 tablespoon of instant flour and
what instant flour is just a very finely
ground flour that really dissolves
fairly quickly give the jar a really
good shake dissolving the flour into the
stock slowly add your thickened stock
mixture here and now bring this back up
to a boil and simmer your gravy until
it's a nice thick and reduced I'm going
to add our defatted juices here give
this a good stir season it with some
salt and pepper if you want it to add
any herbs this would be the point to do
so strain through a fine mesh strainer
so that any of those little bits of
chicken come out of your gravy and so
there you have it a clever way to get
your turkey gravy on the Thanksgiving
table without any pan drippings kitchen
conundrum solved
